Posts.Content: wouldn't rush it mine took 18 months to start working with the blue pills! did the regular vac pump prior to that too. it's still not like it was but as my Urologist says "you have a lot going on!"
Posts.Title: 18 Month Post Op

Posts.Content: Just a few thoughts: You have waited this long why do it now when your PSA basically hasn't changed? According to nonograms the risk of waiting until 0.1 is hardly discernable from 0.03 Why Proton?? you don't have a specific target so isn't standard radiation better in this circumstance? Have you thought about a PSMA scan? Proton is better with a clear target? How did the initial staging jump from T1 to T3B ? Sounds like a lot of cancer to "miss"?
Posts.Title: Anyone undergo radiation with a 0.01 PSA?

Posts.Content: Just a few thoughts: You have waited this long why do it now when your PSA basically hasn't changed? According to nonograms the risk of waiting until 0.1 is hardly discernable from 0.03 Why Proton?? you don't have a specific target so isn't standard radiation better in this circumstance? Have you thought about a PSMA scan? Proton is better with a clear target? How did the initial staging jump from T1 to T3B ? Sounds like a lot of cancer to "miss"?
Posts.Title: Anyone undergo radiation with a 0.01 PSA?

Posts.Content: Hi first post so some history: PSA monitored since age 40 due to fathers death from PC 4 years ago PSA had crept to 3.2 (aged 51) DRE by GP was normal retested 12 months later and psa was 3.8 GP advised me wait 6 months. 6 months later PSA was 4.2. Against his advice I insisted on seeing a urologist, the urologist sent me for an MRI which showed an area of interest. a subsequent biopsy tested postive for PC all grade 6. I was offered 3 options: monitor, operation or radio therapy. I chose the Davinci option and had it removed 20 months ago. Post op was a nightmare as I developed septicaemia and very nearly "croaked" 3 weeks in hospital with infection in places you don't want it was a nightmare. It turned out the surgeon (well respected 350+ proceedures) had had great difficulty re attaching to my bladder which he belived was the cause of the infection. Once that was out of the way everything else went swimmingly, continence returned despite the catheter being in for 1 month longer than intended. EF has taken 18 months to get close to being sorted (didn't help my wife of 34 years leaving 6 months after my op) I add this as somethings you just don't see coming! probably a non "PC" PC joke in there somewhere! PSA nadir was 0.008 6 months post op and the pathology was upgraded to T3A from T2C but all still grade 6 with my urologist saying it was only "technically" a T3 as the cancer had "just touched" the edge?? Now the bad news, PSA at 12 months post op 0.014, 15 months 0.015, 16 months (different lab) 0.020, finally my present value 20 months out is 0.024. Urologist recommended I see an oncologist for a second opinion (happening on thursday) What do you folks think ? I am now 56 in a new relationship but starting to think I am not going to beat this thing and should just bury my head in the sand and concentrate on enjoying myself???
Posts.Title: PSA rising post op now 0.024

Posts.Content: No antibiotics prior to surgery lots after!
Posts.Title: PSA rising post op now 0.024

Posts.Content: Yes my Urologist re-checks the pathology every time I see him and basically says the same thing : "some people debate classing 6 as cancer" so stop worrying etc etc. then the next PSA has gone up and the debate stars again! The Oncologist appt will be interesting!
Posts.Title: PSA rising post op now 0.024

Posts.Content: Thanks Jim. your style sounds like mine.

Posts.Content: There is a new prediction tool available for non metatstatic prostate cancer that attempts to quantify the benefit of radical treatment V conservative treatment. Here's a link to a preamble..... https://www.nhs.uk/news/cancer/onlin...cer-treatment/ Here's a link to the prediction tool https://prostate.predict.nhs.uk/
Posts.Title: New survival prediction tool

Posts.Title: New survival prediction tool

Posts.Content: Re USPSA I am 30 months post op and my USPSA results have been 0.008, 0.014, 0.015, 0.020, 0.024, 0.030, and the most recent 0.023. I was T3A 3+3 15% tumour. Urologist and second opinions from 2 oncologists and they all say the same no further treatment and some men seem to have a residual PSA regardless of outcome, interestingly one of them associated it with fully functioning erection? ??? Anyway they have told me to take a year out from PSA tests and have some fun!!
Posts.Title: Post-op Pathology

Posts.Content: Hi after a nadir of "less than 0.008" at six months post op my PSA crept up to 0.030 over 2 years. As a result I had 2 second opinions one from an oncologist and one from a URO who specialises in some cutting edge stuff. Both said the same thing - given my pathology wait until 0.1 to consider salvage radotherapy. Having read studies until I can read no more there would appear to be very little clinical benefit to treating below 0.1 UNLESS you have positive margins and/or very high risk post op pathology, in which case you should probably be a candidate for adjuvant treatment anyway. 3 years post OP my PSA has now dropped to 0.023 so I have decided to have a year off PSA testing and concentrate on living life to the full..
Posts.Title: Another rise in PSA, but at ultrasensitive levels. Is this Biochemical recurrence?
